repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
This PR adds missing LSP methods that support `both` message directions. These were missing in the previous script, and are preventing accurate type annotations in the `vim.lsp` module.

This PR also handles the special case where some `string` field should be typed as `vim.lsp.protocol.Method` (specifically in `lsp.Registration` and `lsp.Unregistration`), so that the corresponding objects can benefit from the type checking. This makes sure that the corresponding changes in #36069 won't get reverted by future runs of `gen_lsp.lua`.

comment_data.body: This comment shouldn't be removed. Fixing in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/36185
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -784,12 +788,25 @@ end
 --- | vim.lsp.protocol.Method.ServerToClient.Request
 --- | vim.lsp.protocol.Method.ServerToClient.Notification
 
+--- LSP Request (direction: both)
+--- @alias vim.lsp.protocol.Method.Both.Request
+
+--- LSP Notification (direction: both)
+--- @alias vim.lsp.protocol.Method.Both.Notification
+--- | '$/cancelRequest',
+--- | '$/progress',
+
+--- LSP Message (direction: both).
+--- @alias vim.lsp.protocol.Method.Both
+--- | vim.lsp.protocol.Method.Both.Request
+--- | vim.lsp.protocol.Method.Both.Notification
+
 --- @alias vim.lsp.protocol.Method
 --- | vim.lsp.protocol.Method.ClientToServer
 --- | vim.lsp.protocol.Method.ServerToClient
 
 -- Generated by gen_lsp.lua, keep at end of file.
---- @deprecated Use `vim.lsp.protocol.Method` instead.
+--- @deprecated

comment_data.body:
This is generated by the script, too. I think it's better if I put this change in `gen_lsp.lua` so that it doesn't get overwritten again?

edit: nvm I thought you were editing the generated thing.

comment_data.body: @Davidyz please rebase and re-run the script to make sure that this PR doesn't modify this line.

comment_data.body: We don't want the trailing commas here.
Could you better explain what this `has` variable is for?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -147,30 +147,49 @@ local function write_to_vim_protocol(protocol)
   local output = { '-- Generated by gen_lsp.lua, keep at end of file.' }
 
   do -- methods
-    for _, dir in ipairs({ 'clientToServer', 'serverToClient' }) do
+    for _, dir in ipairs({ 'clientToServer', 'serverToClient', 'both' }) do
       local dir1 = dir:sub(1, 1):upper() .. dir:sub(2)
       local alias = ('vim.lsp.protocol.Method.%s'):format(dir1)
+      local parent_type = {
+        ('--- LSP Message (direction: %s).'):format(dir),
+        ('--- @alias %s'):format(alias),
+      }
       for _, b in ipairs({
-        { title = 'Request', methods = protocol.requests },
-        { title = 'Notification', methods = protocol.notifications },
+        { title = 'Request', methods = protocol.requests, contain_both = false },
+        { title = 'Notification', methods = protocol.notifications, contain_both = true },
       }) do
-        output[#output + 1] = ('--- LSP %s (direction: %s)'):format(b.title, dir)
-        output[#output + 1] = ('--- @alias %s.%s'):format(alias, b.title)
-        for _, item in ipairs(b.methods) do
-          if item.messageDirection == dir then
-            output[#output + 1] = ("--- | '%s',"):format(item.method)
+        if b.methods ~= nil and #b.methods > 0 then
+          output[#output + 1] = ('--- LSP %s (direction: %s)'):format(b.title, dir)
+          output[#output + 1] = ('--- @alias %s.%s'):format(alias, b.title)
+          if dir ~= 'both' and b.contain_both then
+            -- `clientToServer` and `serverToClient` should inherit from `both`
+            output[#output + 1] = ('--- | vim.lsp.protocol.Method.Both.%s,'):format(b.title)
+          end
+
+          vim.list_extend(parent_type, { string.format('--- | %s.%s', alias, b.title) })
+          local has = false -- whether this alias is empty
+          for _, item in ipairs(b.methods) do
+            if item.messageDirection == dir then
+              output[#output + 1] = ("--- | '%s',"):format(item.method)
+              has = true
+            end
+          end
+
+          if not has then

comment_data.body: `vim.lsp.protocol.Method.Both` only has notification methods, not request methods. When `has` is empty, it means there's no methods for this particular combination of method type and direction, and the lines inserted in L162 and L163 should be removed.

comment_data.body:
The other aliases have trailing commas after the string literals. I thought it's better to keep the styling consistent?

Update: Just to clarify, the code that included this commas (L173) were there before my patch. It's the same code that added the commas to the literals under other aliases.
I see. It's kind of weird that we have commas for enums with string literals but not for `vim.lsp.protocol.Method`. It's fine to keep the comma here then.

Hmm, I find it quite confusing to add and then remove stuff to the `output` table. If you can come up with a cleaner way to not insert unnecessary entries in the first place, could we at least rename `has` to something more descriptive?

comment_data.body: This seems a little bit much. Can we just include both these values inline instead of having an additional alias?

Just to clarify, by "inline" you're referring to including the "both" methods in the corresponding "clientToServer" and "serverToClient" aliases, correct? 

I think that makes sense, especially since there are only 2 methods that are "both" atm.

Yes.

I'm also hoping that doing this will simplify the script a bit, as this change currently adds quite a bit of complexity.
The for loop is now mostly reverted to the original, with 1 LOC changed to include `both`.

@@ -287,6 +287,9 @@ local anonym_classes = {}
 --- @return string
 local function parse_type(type, prefix)
   if type.kind == 'reference' or type.kind == 'base' then
+    if type.kind == 'base' and type.name == 'string' and prefix == 'method' then
+      return 'vim.lsp.protocol.Method'
+    end

comment_data.body: In the `lsp.Registration` and `lsp.Unregistration` requests, the `method` field can only be lsp method, so I think it makes sense to set the type to `vim.lsp.protocol.Method`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -287,6 +287,9 @@ local anonym_classes = {}
 --- @return string
 local function parse_type(type, prefix)
   if type.kind == 'reference' or type.kind == 'base' then
+    if type.kind == 'base' and type.name == 'string' and prefix == 'method' then
+      return 'vim.lsp.protocol.Method'
+    end

comment_data.body: Shouldn't this affect the output of the file?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -287,6 +287,9 @@ local anonym_classes = {}
 --- @return string
 local function parse_type(type, prefix)
   if type.kind == 'reference' or type.kind == 'base' then
+    if type.kind == 'base' and type.name == 'string' and prefix == 'method' then
+      return 'vim.lsp.protocol.Method'
+    end

comment_data.body: Yes, that's the purpose. @MariaSolOs did it manually in #36069 without updating `gen_lsp.lua`, which is why this change is not reflected in this PR. The purpose of L290 to L292 is to ensure that the `gen_lsp.lua` script will generate this updated type, instead of reverting them back to `string`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -287,6 +287,9 @@ local anonym_classes = {}
 --- @return string
 local function parse_type(type, prefix)
   if type.kind == 'reference' or type.kind == 'base' then
+    if type.kind == 'base' and type.name == 'string' and prefix == 'method' then
+      return 'vim.lsp.protocol.Method'
+    end

comment_regular_data.body: @lewis6991 It would be good for you to take a look at this one.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: fix(lsp): include missing LSP methods and update type annotations
